title: How to Ebonize Wood

steps.headline: Clean a piece of fine steel wool.
steps.description: Use hot water and dish soap or a household solvent to thoroughly clean a piece of grade #0000 steel wool. Steel wool usually has an oil coating that you’ll need to remove before making the solution. New steel wool is best, as older or rusty wool can leave deposits in the wood’s pores. You can also use non-galvanized iron nails or screws, but steel wool’s fine fibers dissolve better.

steps.headline: Tear up the steel wool.
steps.description: After cleaning it, tear the steel wool into small pieces so it’ll break down faster. Wear a pair of thick gloves when you tear it to prevent splinters.

steps.headline: Fill a glass jar with the steel wool and vinegar.
steps.description: Place the steel wool pieces in a glass jar, then fill the jar with vinegar. Apple cider vinegar works better, but you can use white vinegar if you don’t have any on hand or want to save money. Use a glass jar instead of a metal container, as metal will interfere with the process.

steps.headline: Let the steel wool and vinegar sit for a week.
steps.description: It'll take a week for the steel wool to break down and create the staining solution. Don’t cover the jar unless the cover has a small hole bored into it. The dissolution process will produce gases that need to escape.

steps.headline: Pour the solution through a coffee filter.
steps.description: Use a rubber band to attach a coffee filter to the top of the jar. Pour the contents into another non-metal container to strain the staining solution. Filtering will take several minutes and might feel tedious, but you’ll need to get rid of the solution’s solids. Discard the leftover solids after straining the solution.

steps.headline: Choose a fine grain wood for a more authentic look.
steps.description: Ebony is a fine wood with an almost invisible grain. Go with the finest grain wood available to mimic ebony’s look. Even if it’s a lighter wood and will require more coats, the finished product will look more authentic. Less grainy woods like Northern White Cedar or Hemlock are better choices than oak and other grainy woods.

steps.headline: Complete routing and other machining before ebonizing.
steps.description: The staining process will primarily affect the wood’s surface. Routing, carving, cutting, and other machining will likely expose untreated layers of wood. You’ll have to start from scratch if you don’t complete machining before ebonizing.

steps.headline: Raise the wood’s grain before applying the stain.
steps.description: The ebonizing process involves exposing the wood to lots of moisture, so you’ll have to prepare it by raising the grain. Brush water onto the surface and let it dry. Once it's dry, you'll see tiny, fuzzy whiskers of raised wood.

steps.headline: Sand the raised grain.
steps.description: After you've raised the grain, gently sand it away using 220-grit sandpaper. Use a light touch so you don't burnish the wood, or make the surface too smooth for the stain to absorb. For best results, raise and sand the grain twice before ebonizing.

steps.headline: Brew strong tea to form a reaction with the iron solution.
steps.description: Mix a heaping tablespoon of quebracho bark tea powder with a pint (about half a liter) of hot water until it’s fully dissolved. The tea will add tannins that will chemically react with the iron staining solution. You can find quebracho bark powder online. While it’s great choice because of its high tannin content, you can also just use strong black tea or coffee.

steps.headline: Apply the tea to the wood.
steps.description: Use gentle strokes (instead of hard rubbing) to liberally apply a coat of tea to the wood, and allow it to soak through the surface. Spread out or blot any spots where excess tea has started to pool so the application is as even as possible. If you leave a pool of excess tea on the surface, the colorizing reaction won't penetrate into the wood and the final color might look uneven.

steps.headline: Use a foam or bristle brush to apply the stain.
steps.description: Give the tea five or ten minutes to soak, but apply the staining solution while it’s still damp. Apply the stain using light, uniform strokes, and look at the surface from multiple angles to make sure you’ve covered it evenly. Don’t use the same brush that you used to apply the tea, and try not to cross-contaminate the two liquids. If you don’t keep them separate, the ebonizing reaction will occur in your jars or on the brushes instead of within the wood.

steps.headline: Let the stain dry then lightly sand.
steps.description: Give the stain a few hours to dry after you've applied the first coat. When it's completely dry, lightly sand it with fine grit sandpaper. Don't use hard pressure or make the surface too smooth, or the next coat won't absorb well. A light sand will make the surface receptive to the next coat, but a hard sand will smooth the surface too much for the stain to absorb.

steps.headline: Repeat the application process until you’ve achieved your desired color.
steps.description: Reapply coats until you've created an opaque, deep black color. Be sure to let each coat dry and lightly sand before applying more stain. The number of coats necessary will depend on the starting color of your wood. For example, black walnut is darker and has more natural tannins than red oak, so it'll require fewer coats. You might find that you've reached your overall desired color, but there's some chalkiness. A final tea rinse will get rid it and deepen the color.

steps.headline: Buff gently with a clean, dry rag.
steps.description: After you’ve applied the last coat and allowed it to dry, lightly buff the surface with a clean, dry rag. This will polish the wood and remove any loose iron deposits. Buff the surface until its sheen is even, then it’ll be ready for one last coat of tea.

steps.headline: Apply a final tea rinse.
steps.description: A final tea wash will eliminate any chalkiness in the color, resulting in an intense, natural look. Brush the wood with the last tea coat and let it dry completely.

steps.headline: Buff one more time after the tea is dry.
steps.description: The wood should be dry one to two hours after you apply the final tea wash. When it's completely dry, buff the surface once again with a clean rag for a final polish.
